xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: The Ayala Foundation is a foundation funded by the Ayala Corporation, the principal holding company of one of the largest Philippine family groups. The Foundation also solicits funds from other Ayala Group companies and from third parties. It also benefits from bearing the well-known family name.

organization.$: Institute for Population and Social Research

head.citation-title: Philanthropy in Southeast Asia: Between charitable values, corporate interests, and development aspirations
head.abstracts: This article presents an overview of the evolving state of philanthropy in Southeast Asia, driven by global and local stimuli and shaped by often conflicting notions of charity, development, and business. Despite the lack of a strong enabling environment, new, 'home-grown' foundations and local forms of institutionalized giving continue to emerge. At the same time, changes in the donor landscape and shifts in philanthropic paradigms towards business-like and technocratic approaches affect how development causes are funded. In the process, gaps have begun to appear in how work by civil society organizations on human rights and social justice is funded; this may jeopardize more equitable and inclusive development.

organization.$: Institute for Population and Social Research

ref-info.ref-sourcetitle: Infrastructure in focus: A global picture of organizations serving philanthropy

coredata.dc:description: This article presents an overview of the evolving state of philanthropy in Southeast Asia, driven by global and local stimuli and shaped by often conflicting notions of charity, development, and business. Despite the lack of a strong enabling environment, new, 'home-grown' foundations and local forms of institutionalized giving continue to emerge. At the same time, changes in the donor landscape and shifts in philanthropic paradigms towards business-like and technocratic approaches affect how development causes are funded. In the process, gaps have begun to appear in how work by civil society organizations on human rights and social justice is funded; this may jeopardize more equitable and inclusive development.
coredata.dc:title: Philanthropy in Southeast Asia: Between charitable values, corporate interests, and development aspirations
coredata.prism:publicationName: Austrian Journal of South-East Asian Studies
coredata.dc:publisher: SEAS - Society for South-East Asian Studies
